awd_titl_txt: SDSS 2020: Delivering Innovative Science to the Community
awd_abstract_narration:
The Sloan Digital Sky Survey V (SDSS-V) will be the world's first all-sky, multi-epoch, optical and IR spectroscopic survey.  SDSS-V will create an unprecedented dataset designed to decode the history of the Milky Way, trace the emergence of the chemical elements, understand the inner workings and deaths of stars, investigate the origin of planets, and map the growth of black holes.  It will create a new map of the interstellar gas in the Galaxy and the Local Group, 1,000 times larger than the current state of the art, which is needed in order to quantify the physics that regulate the formation of galaxies and understand the origins of our Milky Way.  These natural experiments allow researchers to probe physical conditions that cannot currently be created in Earth bound laboratories.  The data and analysis tools from SDSS will be fully released to the public providing an accessible platform for all scientists at all institutions as well as critical STEM education from K-12.  In addition to the science, SDSS-V cultivates the world’s next generation of instrumentalists capable of delivering vanguard precision and robotic instrumentation across the optical and infrared spectrum to the world.  The support of these future scientific and technical innovators enhances the national STEM workforce.

The SDSS-V program is a union of three key Mapper projects: The Milky Way Mapper is the only planned infrared, dual-hemisphere survey capable of penetrating interstellar dust to uncover the Galactic archaeological record in all regions of the Milky Way. The Local Volume Mapper’s enormous integral-field spectral map of the interstellar gas and star formation in the nearest galaxies will directly probe the scales at which feedback regulates galaxy growth. The Black Hole Mapper will reveal the nature of cosmic X-ray sources discovered by eROSITA early in its mission and will be the first time-domain spectroscopic survey to probe accretion physics across the full range of black holes in the Universe, from stellar-mass to supermassive.  SDSS-V will undertake a robust program of education, outreach, and workforce development activities that leverage the project's commitment to curating data products and collaborative structures that are open, transparent, and inclusive.  SDSS-V intentionally provides a training ground for the future astronomical infrastructure developers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Pioneering the Spectroscopic Panopticon:  The Achievements of SDSS-V

The Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) has been one of the most influential astronomical surveys in history, mapping the cosmos in unprecedented detail for over two decades. SDSS-V, the latest phase of this groundbreaking project, has pushed the boundaries of our understanding of the universe even further. Amplifying support from the National Science Foundation with private philanthropy, and institutions across the globe, SDSS-V has provided groundbreaking insights into the structure and evolution of our galaxy, the lifecycle of stars, the mysteries of black holes, and the vast distribution of galaxies across cosmic time.

Intellectual Merit: Transforming Our Understanding of the Universe

SDSS-V introduced multiple innovative scientific programs that will enhance our knowledge of the cosmos:

  • The Milky Way Mapper: By collecting spectra of millions of high-resolution infrared spectra of stars across our galaxy, SDSS-V has provided the most detailed map of the structure and formation history of the Milky Way. The survey has traced stellar motions and compositions, shedding light on how our galaxy assembled over billions of years.

  • The Black Hole Mapper: SDSS-V has significantly expanded our catalog of black holes, revealing how these enigmatic objects grow and evolve. By studying the physics of black hole feeding, we have gained crucial insights into the role of these cosmic giants in galaxy evolution.

  • The Local Volume Mapper: For the first time, SDSS-V has provided high-resolution spectroscopic maps of gas and dust in nearby galaxies and our own Milky Way.  Using an innovative new telescope design to make the world's largest on-sky integral field spectrograph, the Local Volume Mapper allows scientists to use the Milky Way as a physics laboratory to better understand how stars and planets form in diverse interstellar environments.

Beyond these key programs, SDSS-V has delivered time-domain spectroscopy, enabling astronomers to observe celestial objects as they change over time. This has led to new discoveries about stellar explosions, variable stars, and the dynamic interactions between stars and their environments.  And it is just the beginning.

Broader Impacts: Engaging the Public and Expanding Access to Science

SDSS is more than a scientific mission.  SDSS is a model for open-access astronomy. The project has released its initial dataset to the public, allowing researchers, educators, and citizen scientists worldwide to explore the universe alongside professional astronomers. Some of the key broader impacts of SDSS-V include:

  • Public Data Releases: SDSS-I through SDSS-V have made a vast database of spectral measurements available to the world, ensuring that its discoveries benefit not only professional astronomers but also students, educators, and amateur astronomers.

  • STEM Education & Outreach: SDSS-V has developed numerous educational initiatives, from classroom resources, to observatory tours, to interactive tools that bring astronomical data to the student. Programs such as the SkyServer and Voyages tools have enabled students to conduct their own scientific investigations using real SDSS data.

  • Removing Barriers: Science is an important element of an educated citizenry.  SDSS-V has actively worked to ensure that the opportunities and tools to do science are not kept behind a narrow gate of opportunity, but returned to each and every citizen through our open data and software platforms.  This open science approach benefits the public and benefits science as it fosters an educated and scientifically capable society.  

The Legacy of SDSS-V

As SDSS-V reaches the end of this NSF-supported phase, its contributions to astronomy will continue to shape research for years to come. The project's final data release will provide an unprecedented resource for future discoveries, enabling scientists to test new theories about the universe's origins, structure, and ultimate fate. The SDSS-V community remains committed to ensuring that this knowledge benefits society, inspiring and enabling future generations to explore the cosmos and pursue careers in STEM fields.  In addition, the SDSS-V community remains committed to ensuring that this opportunity is of broad and general benefit and not just available to a small cadre of researchers.  The software and hardware tools developed to make our robots work, may also help make robots in the factories, airplanes, homes or satellites of the future work.

By mapping the heavens and making its data freely available and usable, SDSS-V has not only expanded our understanding of the universe but also empowered humans, as broadly as possible, to engage with the wonders and discovery potential of astrophysics and the tools required of modernity. The sky is no longer the limit: it is just the beginning.  Ad Astra!

 

 


Last Modified: 03/04/2025
Modified by: Juna A Kollmeier

Images (1 of )
  • The color-code represents the target density of targets for the Black Hole and Milky Way Mapper programs. Dark blue shows areas with few targets, with progressively lighter shades of blue indicating higher target density. Peak density is shown in yellow. Grey shows the Local Volume Mapper footprint
    Kollmeier et al. 2025 & J. Carlberg
    Copyright owner is an institution with an existing agreement allowing use by NSF
    Juna A Kollmeier
    SDSS-V Targeting
  • The SDSS-V Local Volume Mapper is the world's largest on-sky Integral-Field Spectroscopic facility. Each pointing creates a spectral atlas -- an image at every frequency -- roughly the size of the full moon (Left) which allows SDSS to map enormous sky regions like Orion (Right) in spectral lines.
    O. Egorov, K. Kreckel, & G. Blanc
    Copyrighted
    Juna A Kollmeier
    Toward Spectroscopic Panopticon
  • The SDSS-V Focal Plane System contains 500 robotic fiber positioning robots that each carry 3 fibers: one for positioning, one that goes to the SDSS infrared spectrographs (APOGEE-N and APOGEE-S) and one that goes the SDSS optical spectrographs (BOSS-N and BOSS-S).
    The Ohio State University Instrument Science Lab
    Creative Commons
    Juna A Kollmeier
    The SDSS-V Dual Focal Plane Systems
  • A schematic image showing the SDSS-V three science mappers � the Milky Way Mapper, the Black Hole Mapper, and the Local Volume Mapper which each create new spectroscopic maps of the sky.
    M. Seibert & J. Kollmeier
    Copyrighted
    Juna A Kollmeier
    SDSS-V At A Glance
  • A map of the spatial distribution of median stellar ages across the Milky Way, projected onto the R (Galactocentric radius) versus Z (height above the Galactic plane) plane. The age and chemical gradients and structural features in these maps allow us to perform "Galactic Archaeology".
    Alexander Stone-Martinez
    Copyrighted
    Juna A Kollmeier
    Age-Dating Stars in the Milky Way
  • SDSS Robots acquire sky targets by moving in the focal plane in overlapping zones. A robot must find the optimal route to its cosmic destination without colliding with another robot. Adapting the mathematics of the famed cocktail party problem, our mighty G-team figured this out fast + efficiently.
    Conor Sayres & Jose Sanchez-Gallego
    Copyrighted
    Juna A Kollmeier
    Robots On The Sky

Pioneering the Spectroscopic Panopticon: The Achievements of SDSS-V


The Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) has been one of the most influential astronomical surveys in history, mapping the cosmos in unprecedented detail for over two decades. SDSS-V, the latest phase of this groundbreaking project, has pushed the boundaries of our understanding of the universe even further. Intellectual Merit: Transforming Our Understanding of the Universe

The Milky Way Mapper: By collecting spectra of millions of high-resolution infrared spectra of stars across our galaxy, SDSS-V has provided the most detailed map of the structure and formation history of the Milky Way. The Black Hole Mapper: SDSS-V has significantly expanded our catalog of black holes, revealing how these enigmatic objects grow and evolve. By studying the physics of black hole feeding, we have gained crucial insights into the role of these cosmic giants in galaxy evolution.




The Local Volume Mapper: For the first time, SDSS-V has provided high-resolution spectroscopic maps of gas and dust in nearby galaxies and our own Milky Way. Using an innovative new telescope design to make the world's largest on-sky integral field spectrograph, the Local Volume Mapper allows scientists to use the Milky Way as a physics laboratory to better understand how stars and planets form in diverse interstellar environments.




Beyond these key programs, SDSS-V has delivered time-domain spectroscopy, enabling astronomers to observe celestial objects as they change over time. This has led to new discoveries about stellar explosions, variable stars, and the dynamic interactions between stars and their environments. And it is just the beginning.

Public Data Releases: SDSS-I through SDSS-V have made a vast database of spectral measurements available to the world, ensuring that its discoveries benefit not only professional astronomers but also students, educators, and amateur astronomers.

This open science approach benefits the public and benefits science as it fosters an educated and scientifically capable society.
